Stay tuned for an upcoming interview with the developer of OSCE-GPT Eddie Guo to learn more about the app and his thoughts on AI in healthcare!

post caption: ^AI OTW: DALL-E AI

profile name: DALL-E is an AI model developed by OpenAI that's redefining creativity and the way we think about images.
DALL-E is like a digital Picasso, creating visual masterpieces from text prompts. It can dream up anything you describe and then render them into stunning images!
The creativity that DALL-E exhibits is awe-inspiring. It's not just limited to the tangible, but extends to abstract concepts, generating artwork that's nothing short of extraordinary.

Beyond the creative applications, DALL-E has potential in industries like design, fashion, and advertising, where it can instantly turn text concepts into visual prototypes. It's like having an AI artist on your team, ready to bring your ideas to life!
Join the AI wave. Become a member at SAIL today for free!

post caption: ^The UofT Branch of 180 Degrees Consulting is recruiting Consultants and Team Leads for the 2022-2023 cycle.

profile name: We offer affordable consulting services to social impact organizations while providing an excellent opportunity for students to engage in real-life consulting projects. 180DC is a global network that provides unparalleled experience in driving social impact, working with clients on real consulting engagements, and collaborating in diverse teams. Consultants will also receive guidance from mentors at Big 4 and MBB firms.
We encourage students of ALL programs and faculties to apply!
Click the link in our bio to apply and see the job descriptions!
Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis - closing at 11:59 PM on Sunday, December 18th.
You may apply to multiple positions; however, only one position will be offered.
Don’t hesitate to email us at uoft@180dc.org or message us on FB/Insta/LinkedIn if you have any questions!^

post caption: ^The UofT Branch of 180 Degrees Consulting is recruiting Consultants and 𝐓𝐞𝐚𝐦 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐬 for the 2022-2023 cycle.

profile name: We offer affordable consulting services to social impact organizations while providing an excellent opportunity for students to engage in real-life consulting projects. 180DC is a global network that provides unparalleled experience in driving social impact, working with clients on real consulting engagements, and collaborating in diverse teams. Consultants will also receive guidance from mentors at Big 4 and MBB firms.
We encourage students of ALL programs and faculties to apply!

𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐚 𝐒𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐃𝐢𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞: A better way to make a difference is to improve the effectiveness of worthwhile organizations! Improved effectiveness means donations go further and more people can be helped both now and in the future.

𝐆𝐞𝐭 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐟𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠: 180 Degrees has worked with leading top-tier consulting firms to develop our own tailored consulting methodology and consulting training program. You will receive professional consulting training from 180 Degrees, often in conjunction with representatives from McKinsey, BCG, Bain, Big 4, or other professional services firms.
𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐝𝐢𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐥𝐲 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐚𝐦𝐚𝐳𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐍𝐨𝐧-𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐨𝐜𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐄𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐬:
You will experience first-hand the fantastic work that many organizations are doing. You will be working on real projects with real clients and will be able to exercise real leadership!
Click the link in our bio to apply and see the job descriptions!
Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis - closing at 11:59 PM on Saturday, August 27th.
You may apply to multiple positions; however, only one position will be offered.
Don’t hesitate to email us at uoft@180dc.org or message us on FB/Insta/LinkedIn if you have any questions!^

post caption: ^We are hiring! The UofT Branch of 180 Degrees Consulting is recruiting executives for the 2022-2023 cycle.

profile name: We are a global organization that offers affordable consulting services to social impact organizations, helping them overcome their unique challenges.

Our executive team is instrumental in this effort. They organize the high-performing teams of student consultants that underpin our work, build successful relationships with new and old clients, and run our branch with an eye toward the future.

If you’re looking to bolster your leadership skills, learn more about consulting, meet like-minded individuals outside your program and bring social impact to those who need it the most, consider applying for the following executive positions:
Our team is made up of students from all backgrounds and disciplines, so we encourage anyone who's interested to apply!
Full postings and application instructions are available here in our bio.

The application deadline is Friday, July 22nd 2022 at 11:59PM. You may apply to more than one position; if so, please rank positions by your preference in the form (you will only submit one statement of interest but make sure you answered the questions for all the positions you applied for).
We are also hosting an info session on July 19th which you can sign up for using the link in our bio.
Applications for Consulting Engagement Managers and Consultants will be open later in August.
Don’t hesitate to email us at uoft@180dc.org or message us on Instagram with any questions!^

post caption: ^Join us for a panel discussion where KPMG consultants representing different business lines will answer your questions related to consulting, their experiences, and the firm! Students will be able to participate in both a panel discussion and networking portion.

profile name: The event will take place on March 31st, from 6 - 7PM EST. Please register using the link in our bio and please don’t hesitate to reach out to our team with any questions. We hope to see you there!^

post caption: ^180 Degrees Consulting is hosting our very own Professional Development Workshop Series to help you ace your next interview and land a summer internship in consulting!

profile name: Our workshops focus on providing students with the necessary toolkit to succeed in any type of case interview. At the end of our series, participants will have the opportunity to network with professionals from large consulting firms! 𝗦𝘂𝗯𝗺𝗶𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲́ 𝗯𝘆 𝗦𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗮𝘆 𝗦𝗲𝗽𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿 𝟭𝟵𝘁𝗵, 𝟭𝟭:𝟱𝟵𝗣𝗠 𝗘𝗦𝗧 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗱. Application form is linked in our bio!

We strive to provide students with the best resources and training to help them reach their full potential. As such, our workshops are divided into five main focus areas: market sizing, profitability case, new product launch, casing math, and behavioural & networking.

Our case partner structure enables you to practice with different students for every workshop. By matching partners based on their experiences, we ensure the right people are being paired together; it is also a great opportunity to get to know like-minded people!
Visit our website for more information: https://www.180dc-uoft.org^

profile name: 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝟭𝟴𝟬𝗗𝗖 𝗦𝘁𝘂𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲?

post caption: ^Join 180 Degrees Consulting UofT as an Engagement Lead and lead consulting projects with social impact organizations! We’re hiring Engagement Leads for the upcoming 2021-22 school year. Applications are due on Sunday, June 6th at 11:59 PM EST and will be reviewed on a rolling basis.!

profile name: Previously known as team leads, each Engagement Lead manages a project team of 4-5 student junior consultants. They are responsible for organizing meeting times, guiding team members, and directly contributing work towards completing engagements. You will greatly influence the quality of work that we deliver to clients, in turn underpinning the social impact that we generate.
This is a great opportunity to gain experience working on real-life consulting projects while contributing to your local non-for-profit community!

profile name: The UofT Branch of 180 Degrees Consulting is recruiting 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭 and 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐓𝐞𝐚𝐦 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐬 for the 2020-2021 cycle.

profile name: I initially joined 180DC because it seemed like a place where I could combine my interests in consulting with my desire to learn more about management. Over the past year, I’ve realized that 180 has the potential to be a proponent of real change and personal development. Our work with clients and the focus on learning and applying concepts we’ve learned in school truly is a unique opportunity to fill in the gaps of traditional education. What’s better, I feel that there is purpose and fulfilment in the work we do, and I’ve made some great friends while I’m at it!

^Wing Commander SKR Bhatt

profile name: Commissioned in 1942. His family was impoverished. He was one of three boys. One brother became a clerk. A second a teacher. SKR Bhatt attended a government school and his elder brother goaded him to finish. He always had a mechanical bent and he went to Madras to look for a job in 1941. He got a job in watch shop while he also did an Engineering course The British were starting to have emergency commissions. Bhatt joined the Air Force as an airman as they desperately needed pilots. He was selected to go to England to train to fly spitfires and hurricanes. According to his son, in Burma, he targeted ammunition dumps on Japanese boats and once when he struck Japanese boat his wing broke. He managed to land safely with two min petrol/gasoline left. Two days later he contracted malaria and was placed on sick leave. On 31st August, 1945, he had a narrow escape from Japanese soldiers who were still fighting the war despite of it being over. Post Malaria, he joined 8 Sqn Indian Air Force. There is a memorial stone in his name in the RAF association’s “Remember A Hero” section of the National Arboretum, Alrewas, UK”.^

post caption: ^ALPHA Education is hosting a screening of the film “Letters from Iwo Jima”.

profile name: Released in 2006 and directed and co-produced by Clint Eastwood, Letters from Iwo Jima tells the “the story of the battle of Iwo Jima between the United States and Imperial Japan during World War II, as told from the perspective of the Japanese who fought it” (The Golden Globe Awards).^

post caption: ^Lt. Colonel Gopal Chakraborty

profile name: Born in Mymensingh, which used to be East Bengal, and is now part of Bangladesh.

Part of the British Army (Indian Army) during World War II, Chakraborty went to Italy serving as a doctor. He was a psychiatrist with the Indian Army, retiring as a Lt. Colonel. He took an early retirement to pursue private practice and became renowned as a psychiatrist.^

post caption: ^Major General Nanavati

profile name:
Will Lt. Colonel Nalin Kumar Dhirajlal Nanavati in a Tuxedo with his wife, Sharda Nanavati. Wearing medals.

Nalin Kumar Dhirajlal Nanavati was born in Rangoon, Burma in 1915, during the British Raj. He was a Surati Baniya from Gujarat. In World War II, he left behind a wife and a young daughter. When the family didn’t hear from him a long time, they assumed that he was killed in the war, and she remarried. But he did return to India after winning a Military Cross for bravery at the crossing of the Rivers Senio and Santerno in Italy by the 8 Indian Division during the period 9-11 Apr 1945. He also fought in the Battle of Monte Cassino. He did remarry (Sharda). He later became the military attaché for India in Moscow. In 1963, He was sent on a non-family posting in Kashmir where he was killed at the age of 45. Other details listed on https://www.indianmemoryproject.com/144.The story on this blog is written by his granddaughter about Sharda.^

post caption: ^Ordinance Artificer W.R. Srinivasan

profile name: “Ordinance Artificer W.R. Srinivasan served in the Royal Indian Navy Service no. 12610 from 23/09/1942 (when he was 24 years old) to 30/11/1947. After independence from Britain, it became the Indian Navy. His time in the navy was a critical period in South Asian history and he spoke about the Navy mutiny against the British during colonial rule. He was an Ordinance Artificer. He served on various ships like HMIS Himalaya, Shamsher and Jamuna, which was the Flagship of the Navy. During World War II, he went to Bahrain, Colombo, Tigris and Euphrates. He also played football for the Naval team and was an advanced yoga practitioner. When he was getting off the ship in Mumbai, he fell into the water when he read the telegram that said that his marriage had been “fixed” or arranged by his parents! Date of birth 15/04/1916. He passed away on 10/05/2016.”^

post caption: ^Three Members of the Women's Royal Naval Service

profile name: Photograph from Ordinance Artificer W.R. Srinivasan. Three members of the Women's Royal Naval Service.

From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_Royal_Naval_Service : "The Women's Royal Naval Service (WRNS; popularly and officially known as the Wrens) was the women's branch of the United Kingdom's Royal Navy. First formed in 1917 for the First World War, it was disbanded in 1919, then revived in 1939 at the beginning of the Second World War, remaining active until integrated into the Royal Navy in 1993. WRNS included cooks, clerks, wireless telegraphists, radar plotters, weapons analysts, range assessors, electricians and air mechanics.”^

post caption: ^Colonel Ilahi Baksh

profile name: “After World War 2 and Partition, Colonel Ilahi Baksh was the doctor to the founder of Pakistan, Muhammed Ali Jinnah. He is also the uncle of Rhode Island Pakistani American artist Saberah Malik”^

post caption: ^This month, we will be featuring photographs compiled by Professor Annu Palakunnathu Matthew at the University of Rhode Island, Department of Art and Art History.

profile name: “As we mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of World War II (WWII), some participated who are barely acknowledged. Including the contributions of the two and a half million Indians who volunteered to take up arms for their British colonial rulers. This erasure is especially astonishing because WWII was truly global, with pivotal conflicts outside the European and Pacific theaters and critical battles in British India and across Asia.

The story of these soldiers has left South Asia with a complex and incomplete narrative of what happened as we gained independence from British colonial rule. These volunteers fought in the mountains of Burma, the hills of Italy, and the deserts of North Africa. They transported artillery, repaired jeeps, cooked, and, under enemy fire, carried the wounded from the battlefield to safety. Thirty of them won Victoria Crosses, England’s highest military honor, and more than eighty-seven thousand died.

These family photographs and stories come from all quadrants of South Asia. Some are from middle-class families, from royalty, and others from low-income families. Some of these soldiers were swashbuckling young men who believed in “the cause.” Others joined out of poverty in search of a regular meal and salary, their hunger exacerbated by the famine (created by the British) that started in Bengal and spread to other parts of India.
These are some of their stories”^

post caption: ^🚨 DATE CHANGE ANNOUNCEMENT - the workshop will be happening on the 28th of January

profile name: ALPHA main will be hosting a super exciting workshop!

Participants will step into the shoes of George MacDonell and Patrick Metallic to gain a greater understanding of the Battle of Hong Kong, the POW experience, and the experiences veterans face upon returning home. George and Patrick are representatives of a greater group of soldiers who served Canada. The social-political conditions that contributed to different post-war life and the changes that have been made since are the foci of this workshop

ALPHA Education and the History Students’ Association @uofthsa is hosting an online educational seminar on Friday, the 19th of November, from 4pm to 5:30pm! This seminar will be the first part of our Overlooked Histories: World War II in Asia series, and will explore the topics of Force 136, the St. Stephen’s College Massacre, and War Crimes at Sea. profile name: “I am making new friends on the streets of Shanghai in 1945. My camera can draw a crowd.”^

profile name: “I was stationed in Chungking in 1945 with a US Navy group called SACO when I took this photograph. I admired their pride and good nature”^

post caption: ^Young Lady In The Field by Roger Moore

profile name: “This young lady has a big job but she can do it. I took this picture in Chungking in 1945.”^

post caption: ^Chinese Gentleman by Roger Moore

profile name: “After the Japanese surrendered WW II in August 1945, I was ordered by the US Navy to Shanghai, China . The Japanese had occupied Shanghai since 1937. I was attracted to the Chinese people for their courage and photographed them.”^

post caption: ^Matriarch by Roger Moore

profile name: “In Shanghai on Soochow Creek , this woman lives with her family on a sampam boat. I took this picture in 1945 shortly after the Japanese surrendered. The boat can be seen in the background.”^

post caption: ^义卖活动圆满结束！

profile name: Unniversity of Toronto Cupid's Arrow (UTCA) hosted a successful Charity Cupcake Sale for Ovarian Cancer Canada, bringing the community together to raise awareness and funds for this important cause.

Students, faculty, and members of the surrounding community gathered to sample and purchase an array of delicious cupcakes；made by local bakers and decorated with the signature teal color of Ovarian Cancer Canada. Throughout the event, attendees had the opportunity to learn about the organization's mission and ways to get involved in their efforts to support those affected by ovarian cancer.
UTCA did a fantastic job of organizing the event and creating a fun and festive atmosphere that encouraged attendees to get involved and support the cause.
With the support of the community, the event was able to raise a substantial amount of money for Ovarian Cancer Canada, which will help further their important work.
The Charity Cupcake Sale was a sweet and meaningful way to bring attention to this important cause and support those affected by ovarian cancer.^
